object.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a solid thing that you can hold, touch, or see but that is not alive
object.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: an everyday object such as a spoon
scientists studying plants, animals, or inanimate objects (=things that are not alive)
object.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the purpose of a plan, action, or activity
object.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: My object was to explain the decision simply.
The customer will benefit most, and that is the object of the exercise (=the purpose of what you are doing).
The object of the game is to improve children’s math skills.
object.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a noun or pronoun representing the person or thing that something is done to, for example ‘the house’ in ‘We built the house.’
object.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a noun or pronoun representing the person or thing that is joined by a preposition to another word or phrase, for example ‘the table’ in ‘He sat on the table.’
object.translation[0].definitions[4].def: the person who is involved in the result of an action, for example ‘her’ in ‘I gave her the book.’
object.translation[0].definitions[5].def: a combination of written information on a computer and instructions that act on the information, for example in the form of a document or a picture
object.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to feel or say that you oppose or disapprove of something
object.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: If no one objects, I would like Mrs Harrison to be present.
Mr Chairman, I object. That is an unfair allegation.
Robson strongly objected to the terms of the contract.
I objected to having to rewrite the article.
object.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to state a fact or opinion as a reason for opposing or disapproving of something
object.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: ‘My name’s not Sonny, ’ the child objected.
The group objected that the policy would prevent patients from receiving the best treatment.
object.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to complain or protest about something, or to feel that you oppose it or disapprove of it
object.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The mayor considered contracting out garbage collection, but the unions objected.
The banks objected to the proposal fiercely.
object.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a solid thing, especially something you can hold or touch
object.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The firms sell products ranging from art objects to vintage cars.
object.translation[3].definitions[1].def: the intended result of a plan, action, activity, or document
object.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Our object is to keep costs down.
The object of a contract of sale is to transfer the property from the seller to the buyer.
Applying for extra amounts in loans defeats the object (=does not have the intended result), because the students then get themselves further into debt.
object.translation[3].definitions[2].def: the things that a company has been formed to do and the types of goods or services that it has been formed to deal in
object.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: The objects of a business dictate what sort of organisation structure it needs.
object.translation[3].definitions[3].def: used to say that you do not care how much money is spent on something
object.translation[3].definitions[3].exa: It would appear that money is no object for the people behind this offer.
object.translation[3].definitions[4].def: a combination of DATA (=written information) and instructions acting on the data, for example in the form of a document or a picture
